docs.lead_paragraph: For the first eight months of her husband's presidency, Michelle Obama has made a practice of steering clear of most policy debates, spending more time in the public eye promoting the White House's vegetable garden than its agenda. But a speech on Friday, which Mrs. Obama delivered to leaders of several women's groups, signaled the beginning of an increased role in the health care debate.
docs.abstract: Michelle Obama, in speech to leaders of several women's groups at Eisenhower Executive Office Building, says that overhauling nation's health care system is critically important to women and is part of next step in their quest to assure full opportunities and equality; photo (S)
docs.snippet: For the first eight months of her husband's presidency, Michelle Obama has made a practice of steering clear of most policy debates, spending more time in the public eye promoting the White House's vegetable garden than its agenda.      But a speech...

docs.lead_paragraph: Uwe E. Reinhardt, a Princeton economist, has a gloomy forecast in assessing Senator Max Baucus's health care proposal. Mr. Reinhardt, right, writing Friday on the Economix blog, says the Baucus plan gives the insurance industry almost everything it could have wanted. But he describes a potential ''winner's curse.'' Because the Baucus plan does little to control runaway medical costs, Mr. Reinhardt says, insurers will still need to raise premiums year after year to keep up -- fueling the rising fury of a public that, under the Baucus rules, would be forced by a federal mandate to buy the increasingly expensive insurance. (Mr. Reinhardt dismisses the proposed insurance alternative, from new nonprofit cooperatives, as ''mice that roar.'')
docs.abstract: Princeton economist Uwe E Reinhardt says that Sen Max Baucus's health care proposal gives insurance industry almost everything it wants and does little to control runaway medical costs; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Uwe E. Reinhardt, a Princeton economist, has a gloomy forecast in assessing Senator Max Baucus's health care proposal. Mr. Reinhardt, right,  writing Friday on the Economix blog, says the Baucus plan gives the insurance industry almost everything it...

docs.lead_paragraph: Investing a few hours time on the Web can help you find the programs and services that may not only ease the financial burden, but may also greatly improve the quality of your elderly parents' lives. Check out these Web sites: NATIONAL COUNCIL ON THE AGING On its benefitscheckup.org Web site, you can find out which federal, state and local government benefits your parents qualify for.

docs.lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, Room for Debate examined how the word "socialism" is used as shorthand and epithet in current politics and in other eras of American history. Many of President Obama's opponents, like those at the demonstration in Washington last weekend, insist that he's a socialist.
docs.abstract: Room for Debate readers found the use of the label "socialism" disturbing, accurate and incendiary.
docs.snippet: Room for Debate readers found the use of the label "socialism" disturbing, accurate and incendiary.

docs.lead_paragraph: Update | 4:48 p.m. The Friday 5 p.m. deadline has passed for filing amendments to the health care legislation in the Senate Finance Committee, and aides to Senator Max Baucus have finished tallying them: 564 in all, from both Democrats and Republicans. The amendments are now on the Senate Finance Committee's website. Following is a sampling submitted by Democratic members of the committee.

headline.main: The Amendments Are In - All 564 of Them

docs.abstract: The Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee are asking for amendments. Here's a sampler.
docs.snippet: The Democrats on the Senate Finance Committee are asking for amendments. Here's a sampler.

docs.lead_paragraph: Timothy Stoltzfus Jost is a law professor at Washington and Lee University and frequently writes on comparative health care policy. His work includes an examination of insurance coverage in Switzerland and a comparison of the Swiss and Dutch systems. He spoke to the freelance writer Anne Underwood.
docs.abstract: Held up as a model for United States, the Swiss health care system achieves universal coverage -- but not cost control.
docs.snippet: Held up as a model for United States, the Swiss health care system achieves universal coverage -- but not cost control.

docs.lead_paragraph: The first lady, Michelle Obama, said Friday that overhauling the nation's health care system was of critical importance to women and part of "the next step" in their long quest to assure full opportunity and equality.

headline.main: Michelle Obama: Health Care Overhaul Is 'Next Step' for Women

docs.abstract: Michelle Obama, rarely involved in public discussions of policy, noted on Friday that women are particularly affected by failures in the present health care system.
docs.snippet: Michelle Obama, rarely involved in public discussions of policy, noted on Friday that women are particularly affected by failures in the present health care system.

docs.lead_paragraph: Monologue | Aired Thursday night on NBC: Well, according to Federal Reserve Chairman Ben Bernanke, he says the recession is over. You know, where is that "You lie!" guy when you need him?

docs.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Matthew Logan went to the Out to Work job fair for gay men and lesbians, and he met representatives for AXA Equitable. Last year, he went to the fair and decided to work for the company. On Thursday, he was back to recruit.
docs.abstract: Thousands of people flocked to a job fair for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgendered people in Greenwich Village on Thursday.
docs.snippet: Thousands of people flocked to a job fair for gay, lesbian, bisexual and transgendered people in Greenwich Village on Thursday.

docs.lead_paragraph: That is the conclusion reported by National Public Radio, in a piece that aired Tuesday morning. The piece was about a program called Healthy San Francisco, which offers uninsured residents access to a network of neighborhood clinics that emphasize preventive and coordinated care. Healthy San Francisco is financed in part by a mandate on companies with 20 or more employees. Companies with up to 100 workers must pay at least $1.23 for every hour worked by each employee to cover that employee's health care costs; those companies that don't provide insurance or other forms of reimbursement pay the minimum to cover the employee's participation in Healthy San Francisco.

headline.main: Is the Employer Mandate a Job Killer? Not in San Francisco.

docs.abstract: Rather than cutting jobs, San Francisco restaurants are passing the cost along to their customers.
docs.snippet: Rather than cutting jobs, San Francisco restaurants are passing the cost along to their customers.
